results.title: The Harp in the South
results.brief_description: Television dramatisation of Ruth Park’s novel following the life and times of a poor Irish Australian family in the aftermath of World War II. This is the poignant saga of the poverty-stricken Darcys of number 12 1/2 Plymouth Street in Surrey Hills - a Sydney slum with its complement of gangs, brothels and sly grog shops.

results.title: The Harp
results.creator_credit: Ken Cameron, Muir Mathieson, Educational Foundation for Visual Aids and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Osian Ellis describes the development of the harp from Biblical times. The complexities of the pedals and their uses, together with various methods of playing are demonstrated. Includes Gavette en Ronda by Bach.

results.title: The Harmony of the worlds
results.creator_credit: Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
All over the world, our ancestors in every culture taught themselves astronomy. Their lives quite literally depended on it. But the journey from the earliest astronomers to the modern day detoured into the pseudo-science of astrology. The last scientific astrologer, was also the first modern astronomer: Johannes Kepler, and this program looks at Kepler’s struggle to find a harmony in the heavens, in the process making the critical step which was to move us into the scientific age.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gregory Andorfer, Polytel International, BBC, Carl Sagan Productions and KCET (Television station : Los Angeles, Calif.)

results.title: The Hare and the Tortoise
results.brief_description: An all-star cast of real animals and birds feature in this charming tale for children, based on Aesop’s fable. The wise old owl acts as judge, the fox lays out the woodland course for the race, the raccoon (who wakes up the sleeping hare, too late, of course), the gossipy goose, the rooster, and the hare and the tortoise, whose contest proves that the race is not always to the swift, all appear.

results.title: The Harder they fall
results.creator_credit: Philip Yordan, Columbia Pictures and Mark Robson
results.brief_description: Eddie Willis is an unemployed newspaperman who sells his soul when he takes on the job of press agent for corrupt boxing promoter, Nick Benko. Willis takes on the task of stirring up publicity for Benko’s newest protege, the clumsy, seven-foot giant, Toro Moreno, who can’t box to save himself. Toro quickly rises to the top through a series of fixed fights, and believes himself a killer not recognising the scam. Willis regains some integrity, however, when he learns that Benko has no intention of paying Toro his share of winnings. He sends Toro home with his own share, and decides to expose the scandal through a series of articles. Cast includes: Humphrey Bogart, Rod Steiger, Jan Stirling, Mike Lane and Max Baer.

results.title: The Harder they come [DVD]
results.brief_description: The first independent feature film produced in Jamaica gave many Americans their first taste of reggae music with musician Jimmy Cliff in the title role, backed by a fabulous reggae soundtrack. Cliff plays Ivan, a naive rural singer who moves to the city in search of fame but is soon impoverished and exploited by the music industry before becoming embroiled in the trade of marijuana and murder; simultaneously Ivan’s music is released to great acclaim and he becomes somewhat of a local anti-hero. As well as offering a unique view of the reggae scene the milieu of this film also offers a de-romanticised view of seedy Kingston life. Indeed Henzell’s style borders on documentary, as he evokes the squalor of the street, the impoverishment of the people and the multi-faceted systemic corruption. Soundtrack includes the title track as well as other reggae hits “You Can Really Get It if You Want It”, “Sitting in Limbo” and “Johnny Too Bad”. Cast includes Basil Keane, Ras Daniel Hartman, Winston Stona, Janet Barkley, Bobby Charlton and Carl Bradshaw.

results.title: The Hard word
results.creator_credit: Al Clark, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Scott Roberts
results.brief_description: Taking its cues from the harder edged of the classic crime genre spectrum (in particular Stanley Kubrick’s The Killing), writer/director Scott Robert’s The Hard word manages to work into the mix some off the wall humour and quirky characterization. Guy Pearce, Joel Edgerton and Damien Richardson star as the Twentyman brothers Dale, Mal and Shane, three hardened criminals serving out a prison sentence for armed robbery. Aided by their very crooked lawyer Frank Malone (a gleefully corrupt Robert Taylor), the brothers are given an early bail release, with one very compromising proviso, they have to pull off a dangerous casino heist. To complicate things further Frank is having an affair with Dale’s wife Carol (played with slutty abandon by Rachel Griffiths). Naturally things go from bad to worse as the heist takes a violent turn and the boys discover that they are being tailed by two dodgy cops (Vince Colossimo and Paul Sonkkila) with an unlawful agenda of their own. Cast includes: Rhondda Findleton, Kym Gyngell, Kate Atkinson.

results.title: The Hard sell
results.creator_credit: Tony Matthews, Paul Ellis and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Small Business”.
How can the smaller firm make money from better marketing? Interviews with business and marketing experts establish several valuable selling approaches. Stresses the importance of making the right product, and keeping production and sales in step. Includes advice on both home and export sales. NB: Dated and “politically incorrect” in some segments.

results.title: The Hard core
results.creator_credit: International Refugee Organization. Office of Public Information and Arthur Zegart
results.brief_description: Film deals with the “hard core” on intellectuals and invalid war victims remaining in the displaced persons’ camps in Europe and shows the steps already taken by the International Refugee Organisation to alleviate the suffering of these special groups and try to find homes for them in other countries.
results.creator_credit_for_label: International Refugee Organization. Office of Public Information and Arthur Zegart

results.title: The Harbour from McMahons Point
results.creator_credit: Malcolm Otton, David Muir and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Australian eye V”.
Strong and rhythmic, rich in detail, this painting comes from Lloyd Rees’ middle period and gives a feeling of intimacy and involvement with its subject. The artist refers to it in the film as “basically a draughtsman’s picture” and gives his personal comments on its composition. The film reveals the range of Lloyd Rees’ work and his architectural strength and ends with his Turneresque late landscapes, while the sound-track is enhanced by his comments on the problems of plein-air painting and thoughts on the importance of drawing.
